ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Really helpful, and you get breakfast goodies every morning!

I strongly believe that the year-long sociology thesis is the better option, and here's a whole slew of reasons why... 1) You get far more time to craft a better finished product. 2) The seminar only meets every other week--and Professor Smith will make sureto feed you! 3) You have the opportunity to watch your classmates' projects unfold over the entire year--which has so far been really cool. 4) You can't graduate with honors in the Sociology major unless you write a year-long thesis. 5) You get to take a seminar with Professor Smith, who is delightful. AND, 6) last but certainly not least, you get the added bonus of actually getting to know about a dozen people in your major. So long as you have an inkling as to what you might write about, the year-long option seems to be the way to go. Enjoyable class, steady but reasonable pace, and keeps you on target to finish your thesis well ahead of the deadline.

Year-long senior thesis - it's a lot of fun to go through the process with your fellow majors, highly recommended, don't be daunted - most of us don't seem to get our act together until mid-way through the semester.

The sociology department has by far the best method of getting seniors through their senior essay. With an advisor, a teaching fellow AND the DUS of your department leading your senior essay colloquium, it's very difficult to go wrong here! I highly recommend pursuing the year-long route as it's much more rewarding and less stressful than the semester-long thesis, but that's just me. Good luck!
